title: What would the Universe be like if the vacuum did not exist? - Quora

response.answer_text: A2A If you're going to propose a hypothetical situation that eliminates one law of physics you are free to change any other laws of physics in any manner you wish to. So, if you do away with empty space are you in replace it with something? I going to jam everything together? Are you going to put air in between objects? Going to have objects? Do you have gravity? Do you have matter at all? Do you have atoms? Are you going to have electrons protons and neutrons? Are you going to have forces and accelerations? Get the idea?

In a way, the vacuum doesn’t exist, and that’s what gives it its power. It is only energy created by the sucking of nonexistence. If it didn’t have energy, then our universe wouldn’t have come into existence, at least not in the way we know it.

A vacuum by definition is not a thing. A vacuum is the absences of all gaseous and liquid materials. So to answer your question I guess the whole universe would be a solid mass which would be impossible to exist.
Like a black hole or rather singularity point since the mass and density of the university would be so great that it simply collapsed.
